Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Stubbed \Stub"bed\, a. 1. Reduced to a stub; short and thick, like something truncated; blunt; obtuse. [1913 Webster]
2. Abounding in stubs; stubby. [1913 Webster]
A bit of stubbed ground, once a wood. --R. Browning. [1913 Webster]
3. Not nice or delicate; hardy; rugged. ``Stubbed, vulgar constitutions.'' --Berkley. [1913 Webster]

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Stub \Stub\, v. t. [imp. & p. p. {Stubbed}; p. pr. & vb. n. {Stubbing}.] 1. To grub up by the roots; to extirpate; as, to stub up edible roots. [1913 Webster]
What stubbing, plowing, digging, and harrowing is to a piece of land. --Berkley. [1913 Webster]
2. To remove stubs from; as, to stub land. [1913 Webster]
3. To strike as the toes, against a stub, stone, or other fixed object. [U. S.] [1913 Webster]

stub n 1: a short piece remaining on a trunk or stem where a branch is lost 2: a small piece; "a nub of coal"; "a stub of a pencil" [syn: {nub}] 3: a torn part of a ticket returned to the holder as a receipt [syn: {ticket stub}] 4: the part of a check that is retained as a record [syn: {check stub}, {counterfoil}] 5: the small unused part of something (especially the end of a cigarette that is left after smoking) [syn: {butt}] v : strike against an object; "She stubbed her one's toe in the dark and now it's broken" [syn: {scrape}, {skin}, {abrade}] [also: {stubbing}, {stubbed}]
